articles.headline: ‘There’s Probably Never Been More Uncertainty,’ Fed Official Warns
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve policymakers underlined economic risks, yet the central bank’s point man on supervision suggested regulators would not disclose how specific banks might fare.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve policymakers underlined economic risks, yet the central bank’s point man on supervision suggested regulators would not disclose how specific banks might fare.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials warned on Friday that the U.S. economic outlook remained wildly uncertain, as parts of the country see a new surge in coronavirus infections.

articles.headline: Black Tulsans, With a Defiant Juneteenth Celebration, Send a Message to Trump
articles.snippet: The president arrives in a city that is in the midst of addressing long-ignored racist history. People there believe the country as a whole could learn a lot from them.
articles.abstract: The president arrives in a city that is in the midst of addressing long-ignored racist history. People there believe the country as a whole could learn a lot from them.

articles.headline: Social Media Giants Support Racial Justice. Their Products Undermine It.
articles.snippet: Shows of support from Facebook, Twitter and YouTube don’t address the way those platforms have been weaponized by racists and partisan provocateurs.
articles.abstract: Shows of support from Facebook, Twitter and YouTube don’t address the way those platforms have been weaponized by racists and partisan provocateurs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several weeks ago, as protests erupted across the nation in response to the police killing of George Floyd, Mark Zuckerberg wrote a long and heartfelt post on his Facebook page, denouncing racial bias and proclaiming that “black lives matter.” Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, also announced that the company would donate $10 million to racial justice organizations.

articles.headline: After 15 Years, Apple Prepares to Break Up With Intel
articles.snippet: Apple could announce plans as soon as Monday to replace Intel processors in Macs with chips that it designed itself.
articles.abstract: Apple could announce plans as soon as Monday to replace Intel processors in Macs with chips that it designed itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Silicon Valley is bracing for a long-expected breakup of Apple and Intel, signaling both the end of one of the tech industry’s most influential partnerships and Apple’s determination to take more control of how its products are built.
articles.byline: By Don Clark and Jack Nicas

articles.headline: U.S. Watched George Floyd Protests in 15 Cities Using Aerial Surveillance
articles.snippet: From Minneapolis to Buffalo, Homeland Security officials dispatched drones, helicopters and airplanes to monitor Black Lives Matter protests.
articles.abstract: From Minneapolis to Buffalo, Homeland Security officials dispatched drones, helicopters and airplanes to monitor Black Lives Matter protests.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND FORKS, N.D. — The Department of Homeland Security deployed helicopters, airplanes and drones over 15 cities where demonstrators gathered to protest the death of George Floyd, logging at least 270 hours of surveillance, far more than previously revealed, according to Customs and Border Protection data.

articles.headline: W.H.O. Warns of ‘Dangerous Phase’ of Pandemic as Outbreaks Widen
articles.snippet: Beijing and Seoul have had a recent surge in coronavirus cases, and businesses are recoiling in America as infections sharply increase in Southern and Western states.
articles.abstract: Beijing and Seoul have had a recent surge in coronavirus cases, and businesses are recoiling in America as infections sharply increase in Southern and Western states.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The world has entered a “new and dangerous phase” of the coronavirus pandemic, a top official from the World Health Organization said on Friday, a stark warning that came as the United States struggled to control spiraling outbreaks and as business leaders signaled growing unease with the country’s ability to effectively contend with the virus.

articles.headline: The Walls of the Church Couldn’t Keep the Trump Era Out
articles.snippet: The young pastor wasn’t sure his congregation would like what he had to say and had no idea where it would lead all of them. He found himself at a crossroads of God, Alabama and Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: The young pastor wasn’t sure his congregation would like what he had to say and had no idea where it would lead all of them. He found himself at a crossroads of God, Alabama and Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILLIAMS, Ala. — In early 2017, a pastor in the Alabama countryside named Chris Thomas prepared to give his Sunday sermon. President Trump had been inaugurated the week before, and the new administration was already making headlines with a travel ban that included refugees from Syria.

articles.headline: Latin America’s Virus Villains: Corrupt Officials Collude With Price Gougers for Body Bags and Flimsy Masks
articles.snippet: The coronavirus has devastated Latin America. And it has only been worsened by a wave of graft and profiteering, prosecutors say.
articles.abstract: The coronavirus has devastated Latin America. And it has only been worsened by a wave of graft and profiteering, prosecutors say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the schemes that have siphoned resources from Latin American countries fighting the coronavirus, the body bag conspiracy might be the most brazen.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Mitra Taj

articles.headline: Trump Rally Fizzles as Attendance Falls Short of Campaign’s Expectations
articles.snippet: President Trump’s attempt to revive his re-election bid sputtered badly as he traveled to Tulsa for his first mass rally in months but found a small crowd and delivered a disjointed speech.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s attempt to revive his re-election bid sputtered badly as he traveled to Tulsa for his first mass rally in months but found a small crowd and delivered a disjointed speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — President Trump’s attempt to revive his re-election campaign sputtered badly on Saturday night as he traveled to Tulsa for his first mass rally in months and found a far smaller crowd than his aides had promised him, then delivered a disjointed speech that did not address the multiple crises facing the nation or scandals battering him in Washington.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: ‘They Just Dumped Him Like Trash’: Nursing Homes Evict Vulnerable Residents
articles.snippet: Nursing homes across the country are kicking out old and disabled residents and sending them to homeless shelters and rundown motels.
articles.abstract: Nursing homes across the country are kicking out old and disabled residents and sending them to homeless shelters and rundown motels.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a chilly afternoon in April, Los Angeles police found an old, disoriented man crumpled on a Koreatown sidewalk.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Amy Julia Harris

articles.headline: Trump Seeks a Cultural Safe Space Amid a Deadly Pandemic
articles.snippet: In his first rally since the global coronavirus pandemic suspended the campaign trail, President Trump played the hits.
articles.abstract: In his first rally since the global coronavirus pandemic suspended the campaign trail, President Trump played the hits.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla. — The difference between a rally for Joseph R. Biden Jr. and one for President Trump starts with the attire.

articles.headline: New Hope for White-Collar Job Seekers? It Depends on the Job
articles.snippet: The hiring trough seems to have passed, but most opportunities are with the industries least buffeted by the coronavirus shutdown.
articles.abstract: The hiring trough seems to have passed, but most opportunities are with the industries least buffeted by the coronavirus shutdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shawn Banerji’s services do not come cheap. A top headhunter, he typically has several searches underway at once, each of which can cost the companies that hire him a six-figure retainer.

articles.headline: Vast Federal Aid Has Capped Rise in Poverty, Studies Find
articles.snippet: But researchers caution this does not mean low-income families are escaping hardship. And they warn that when the aid expires next month, families could again be vulnerable.
articles.abstract: But researchers caution this does not mean low-income families are escaping hardship. And they warn that when the aid expires next month, families could again be vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An unprecedented expansion of federal aid has prevented the rise in poverty that experts predicted this year when the coronavirus sent unemployment to the highest level since the Great Depression, two new studies suggest. The assistance could even cause official measures of poverty to fall.

articles.headline: 8 Hospitals in 15 Hours: A Pregnant Woman’s Crisis in the Pandemic
articles.snippet: Her baby was coming, and her complications were growing more dangerous. But nowhere would take her — an increasingly common story as India’s health care system buckles under pressure.
articles.abstract: Her baby was coming, and her complications were growing more dangerous. But nowhere would take her — an increasingly common story as India’s health care system buckles under pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Neelam Kumari Gautam woke up at 5 a.m. with shooting labor pains. Her husband put her gently in the back of a rickshaw and motored with her to a hospital. Then another. Then another. Her pain was so intense she could barely breathe, but none would take her.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: The Lapses That Let a Saudi Extremist Shoot Up a U.S. Navy Base
articles.snippet: The gunman who killed three in Florida was not directed by Al Qaeda, nor inspired solely by online ideology. He was a new kind of terrorist, harder to spot: an extremely enterprising freelancer.
articles.abstract: The gunman who killed three in Florida was not directed by Al Qaeda, nor inspired solely by online ideology. He was a new kind of terrorist, harder to spot: an extremely enterprising freelancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump stepped before the cameras at a White House news conference less than a month after his inaugural and declared that he was already taking bold steps to keep “radical Islamic terrorists” out of the United States.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: What’s Facebook’s Deal With Donald Trump?
articles.snippet: Mark Zuckerberg has forged an uneasy alliance with the Trump administration. He may have gotten too close.
articles.abstract: Mark Zuckerberg has forged an uneasy alliance with the Trump administration. He may have gotten too close.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Nov. 20, NBC News broke the news that Mark Zuckerberg, Donald Trump and a Facebook board member, Peter Thiel, had dined together at the White House the previous month. “It is unclear why the meeting was not made public or what Trump, Zuckerberg and Thiel discussed,” the report said.

articles.headline: For Barr, Standoff With Prosecutor Adds to String of Miscues
articles.snippet: The attorney general has found himself at odds with the White House on high-profile issues in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: The attorney general has found himself at odds with the White House on high-profile issues in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the onset of his tenure, William P. Barr has been billed as the attorney general that President Trump was looking for. And Mr. Barr has taken some pride in this role, telling Fox News this past weekend that he speaks with the president “very regularly.”
articles.byline: By Katie Benner and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: What’s Gotten Into the Price of Cheese?
articles.snippet: Shifts in pandemic demand have wreaked havoc on a market that’s rarely so volatile.
articles.abstract: Shifts in pandemic demand have wreaked havoc on a market that’s rarely so volatile.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wholesale market for Cheddar is typically a mild one. But the vagaries of supply and demand during the pandemic have caused sharp swings in cheese prices, which rose to record highs this month — just weeks after plummeting to nearly 20-year lows.
